name: Kepler-32
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-32 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-32 is a star with 0.58 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.53 times its radius. It is located 1066.04 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-32 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-32 b

Kepler-32 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2012-05. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.90 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-32.

The mass of Kepler-32 b is 1303.02 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-32 b is 2.2 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-32 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.

Kepler-32 c

Kepler-32 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2012-05. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.75 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-32.

The mass of Kepler-32 c is 158.91 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-32 c is 2 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-32 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.

Kepler-32 d

Kepler-32 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2013-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 22.78 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-32.

The mass of Kepler-32 d is 10.45 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-32 d is 2.7 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-32 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-32 e

Kepler-32 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2013-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.90 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-32.

The mass of Kepler-32 e is 2.55 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-32 e is 1.5 that of Earth. At 2.55 Earth masses, Kepler-32 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-32 f

Kepler-32 f was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2013-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.01 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 0.74 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-32.

The mass of Kepler-32 f is 0.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-32 f is 0.82 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-32 f is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-32, which contains 5 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
